4- MQUIOGS. Of 99.95.
The eggs should firsT be sTudied in The condiTion in which They are spawned, buT
for many purposes iT is desirable To prepare Them for microscopic sfudy as follows;
roll The eggs on a piece of fi|Ter paper or paper Towel unTil The jelly and The ouTer
fibres are removed, leaving The surface of The chorion smooTh and clean. The
same procedure should be followed for day-old sTock culfures in order To prevenT
clumpihg of The eggs.
For experimenTal work eggs are usually examined uncovered in shallow depression
slides or Syracuse dishes and manipulaTed wiTh hair loops. For laboraTory sTudy
where eggs are To be observed over long periods of Time and specific orienTaTion
is desired, eiTher of The following meThods is suggesTed: Place The eggs in
sea waTer in culTure slides having a l.7 and l.8 mm. depression less
Than The diameTer of The egg). The egg may now be roTaTed by moving The cover
slip. lf These special slides are noT available eggs may be placed in a drop of
sea waTer on an ordinary glass slide and covered wiTh a very Thin, flexible sheeT
of mica. waTer is Then wifhdrawn wiTh lens paper unTil capillary aTTracTion
causes a pressure roTaTed as in The previous meThod.
5. PermanenT ToTal PreparaTion?,
Fix The eggs in STockard's soluTion. This Turns The proToplasm whiTe buT leaves
The yolk TransparenT. The fixaTive may be used as a preservafive or The maferial
may be Transferred To IOZ formalin afTer 2 days.
6. gPrep&raTion 
For fixafion and embedding meThods, consulT insTrucTor.
B. Gunner and oTher Pelagic Eggs
Whenever possible, observaTions should be made on pelagic eggs as well as on The
demersal eggs of Fundulus. Many sTrucTures such as The germ-ring, embryonic shield,
and Kupffer's vesicle will be easier To see in The former because They have fewer
oil globules and a less-granular porToplasm. The formafion of polar bodies may
also be seen in This Type of egg. Pelagic eggs are far more sensITive, however,
in Their oxygen requiremenTs, so require careful handling.
Gunners should be caughT The same day as needed; females are ordinarily obTained
only afTer l2M. The male is a somewhaT brighTer green color and can also be 
disTinguished by iTs brighT red cloacal lining epiThelium. MilT is sTripped inTo
a large finger bowl which conTains sufficienT sea waTer To cover The boTTom. iT
will prove helpful To use a cloTh Towel or work-gloves for holding The fish while
They are being sTripped, because They are exfremely slimy and have sharp spines
in The dorsal fin.. i
As soon as possible afTer sTripping, The sperm-suspension should be poured inTo
The egg dish and The Time recorded. The mixTure sTand for half a minuTe; Then
diluTe wiTh sea waTer and decanf inTo smaller finger bowls, or pour inTo a
cylinder or Erlenmeyer flask and add sufficienT sea waTer To fill. Good eggs will
floaT on The Top and collecT principally aT The edge of The menlscus. They should
be pipeTTed off and placed in covered finger-bowls confaining l/4" of clean sea
waTer, and seT in The sea waTer Table where They will keep cool.
